Yeah, so when you ask me about what do I remember about Wales and what is Wales to me,
that is, I can vividly remember some of the things that happened to me even when I was a very, very small child going to school in Wales.
I was born in Pembrokeshire which is on the West Coast and actually I was born in Neath but at three months old I was not.
But my school days were mainly in Tredegar, a school called Nantibu School.
Our schools at that time were nearly all managed and Headmaster was an ex-military man.
Discipline was the, you did what you were told whether it was right or whether it was wrong.
You had no, I learned at a very early age that you weren't allowed to think or express your own opinions.
When I, during the first war started, I was very young, I went back to school,
but this was at Pembroke Dock because my father had been called up.
And when I went back in 1972, I visited the school and the motto of that school is the motto that has kept me through all my life.
And it's been my guide and it's, I'd like to repeat it for everybody to know.
And if I had my way, I'd have it said the same as we did, recite it every morning in the school.
Do the right because it is right. Do your duty at any cost. Keep your word when one's given.
Abort mean actions. Help the weak and those that are down.
Now that to me, any person that wants to live up to that will be successful.
Having said that, you could imagine what was my, and having had the background that I had two strikes,
been quite active from the time I was very young in the mine.
My father dying, a young man in the prime of his life because of the mining.
The friends, brothers, some being killed in the mine, some maimed in the mine.
This then brought us into what has been my whole life and what has been the background of a lot of Welshmen that I know.
And that is that there wasn't enough room in Wales for us.
The freedom wasn't there. The oppression was.
We weren't running away from oppression. We were running, we were trying to get away, I think, for our freedom.
In fact, I came out here, one of 10,000 miners who had been shipped out to Canada for no other reason
than they were afraid that there would be an upheaval, that there would have been a revolution.
There is no doubt about it, in 1928, after the 26th strike, that there was the unemployment.
We came out to get the harvest in with the option of going back if we wished, and I said I'd never go back.
I never have. But I have, my background has been the trade union movement, was organising people.
I'm mostly concerned with the underprivileged groups.
The aristocracy of labour, they could look after themselves. It was the hospital workers, it was the store workers,
the engineers, labourers and construction trades. Those were the people I was interested in, and I spent all my life here in Canada with them.
Now I'm with the pensioners and pioneers. They're president now, although I helped to organise them in 1939.
And the unemployed groups and things like that, now I'm their president, and we have some good organisations.
I have found out that the majority of Welsh people in Canada have been workers, honest workers,
and they've all done very well, very, very few. The ones that couldn't make it here didn't even stay, they went back home.
So we don't have too many Welsh people in Canada who are what we call destitute in that manner.
We have helped a lot of old, old people. That's part of our making.
In Saskatoon, in particular, when I came here, the friends were the Welsh society, and we had a good Welsh society.
We would try to get work for our own people. It went, and the reason that it goes is like the same reason for all the other groups,
the Ukrainian or the German or anybody else, is immigration. And if we don't have the Welsh people immigrating out here,
then we don't have the new blood coming in. It's the same with all the others, the Italians or anybody else.
So we suffered when we didn't get the immigrants. And of course, it's the same thing here in Saskatoon,
our climate being what it is in the wintertime, and it's hard, it's a hard life on the prairies at the best of times.
Then you are inclined to go to the warmer climate or drift to the heavier, developed places.
And I could go to Vancouver and I could meet more Welsh people than I have in Saskatoon now, that have been in Saskatoon some time or another.
Of course, our university, we have quite a few in there, and the intellectual group, that was quite a few.
But then they don't seem to, there's always been, seem to have been that division between what we call the work in Welsh and the intellectual Welsh.
And I think you'll find this all the way through Canada too. But as I say, when I came here, and there was only a few of us,
but we were well received and we built up, then it went down, and now it's coming back again, because we did have quite a few younger people coming out.
What the main mistake we made was that we didn't retain our culture and develop it in our, I have three children who are, who now they're grown up, say,
that the biggest crime that was ever committed to them was that we didn't teach in the Welsh language, in the Welsh culture.
This is the, I have a son who is on TV and radio, and they claim to be Welsh. They claim to be Welsh. They want to be Welsh.

was the county where the English had taken over and they practically killed the Welsh language.

It was in Wales, all right. He claimed to be a Welshman. But that is England beyond Wales, which was worse than Monmouthshire as far as the culture and the language.

And I've been interested in all of it. So, you see, a lot of the things that have been done here were done by Welshmen. So we have nothing to be ashamed of, but we've got everything to be proud of outside of the things that we are ashamed of ourselves.
But if we had done as much for ourselves as a group, as we have done for other, or the main part of the people as a population, we would have had Welsh classes at other universities, and we would have our own culture, our Western Development Museum, we would have a Welsh section, I'm sure, because a lot of the pioneers,
